@72103-i you don't need software. You just need screencapture. You can actually frame the screengrab in such as way that it avoids the watermark. When you use software to removed the watermark there is still an inaudible fingerprint stuck in the audio part of the video and screencapture tends to remove that too. But even that can be removed through multiple layers of processing. With AI generated music the fingerprinting or audio watermark can often be removed through an advanced mastering process for example. The folks at SUNO for example don't like it when you master the output you get their AI because it damages the watermark to the point it becomes almost not detectable.

‚Äã@NiaLaLa_V that's still way less of a barrier though, and that's the point. You don't need a team of people, you don't even need some photoshop skills. You Just need either a bit of time to save up free credits, or to pay, and that's it. Anyone at all can take the most stupid misinformation and put it out there in an increasingly realistic way. That's a huge difference from when only a few people could Produce something in a convincing way

I use AI on occasion for local news videos. It's like puppetry. I tend to keep the AI watermark on mine. But it is possible to remove for a fee or using screencapture software. The way to verify non original information presented by an Ai broadcast is to look at other sources just as you would for human broadcasts. I also use it for music. This is more of a mix and master kind of thing though as I work with multiple AI platforms, SUNO, Riffusion, and AIVA. and what I do is download the stems and mix stems from the three different platforms together and on occasion with real life stuff. This makes it near impossible to determine if song or instrumental was created by AI so I have to disclose this in the notes. Usually something "Created using SUNO and Audacity" and if I use a real instrument I will include that instrument as well. But my recent understanding is that the streaming services, my music is on Spotify, Iheartradio, and other platforms, they access the notes section of the metadata. They should check the notes section because some artists using AI do put notes there indicating they used AI. This is just in case we want to redo it in the future. We can check the metadata to see how we did it the first time. My spotify say the songs have synthesized voices because AI platforms were really just high advanced and autonomous sound and image synthesizers. Some people may have a hesitation to being required to use the term AI which is why it is better to use the term synthesized instead because it means the same thing: artificially created with advanced autonomous software or AAS. Now the million dollar question is: You create a song on different AI platforms. In my case, I use the same tempo, key, instruments, genre, emotions, themes, etc on all three. Then you download the stems from all three. And say you use audacity or reaper and you mix the stems you like together which actually creates something new and which clearly indicates the song was human created or human directed. It also makes it impossible for software to determine if the song was AI generated because while each stem has a watermark, this process can remove the watermark but in most cases damages it to the point that detection algorithms can't see it. This is why you put "created using SUNO, Riffusion, AIVA, and whatever else you used" into the metadata. Speaking of which, it turns out that music created this way is copyrightable because of the human input, direction, and arrangement.

I want to respond to a few misconceptions in this thread‚Äîespecially about how AI works and who really understands it. I‚Äôve been using and experimenting with AI for over three years, testing dozens of platforms for both music and video production. My goal has always been to find tools that give more creative control, not less. When I say something isn‚Äôt original or is likely replicating existing content, that‚Äôs not a guess‚Äîit‚Äôs based on real use. I stopped uploading videos to YouTube for nearly a year because the AI tools at the time were still stuck in what I call the ‚Äúslop phase.‚Äù Output was messy, inconsistent, and in many cases, the models were clearly using data that felt suspiciously familiar‚Äîlike they‚Äôd been trained on copyrighted or torrented content from sites like PirateBay or similar. In fact, when you see an AI tool recreate a journalist‚Äôs voice and report almost exactly, that‚Äôs not ‚Äúnew‚Äù creation‚Äîthat‚Äôs replication. And that kind of accuracy raises serious ethical questions about how that model was trained. No legitimate model should be able to do that unless it was trained on her original videos without permission. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm now much more selective about the platforms I use. For visuals, I use Moonvalley, which trains its models on ethically sourced data and gives me consistency across clips so I can tell a story‚Äînot just string together random images. Their Marey character is a major step forward in making AI work with artists instead of against them. For music, I use AIVA, because unlike prompt-only systems, it gives me full creative control‚Äîgenre, key, instruments, mood, tempo, and more‚Äîand it‚Äôs also trained on legally licensed music, not pirated material. I‚Äôve also been using Riffusion when I want to fine-tune vocal phrasing or experiment with the sound of the voice itself. If I wanted to, I could even upload my own voice for more personal expression. Suno is trying to move in this direction, but it still has a way to go. So to the commenter who said I "don‚Äôt know how AI works"‚ÄîI‚Äôve been working directly with it for years, not watching from the sidelines. AI isn‚Äôt magical. It needs direction‚Äîand when that direction comes from a creator who understands the story they want to tell, AI becomes a tool, not a threat. But let‚Äôs not pretend AI doesn‚Äôt come with risks. If a model is recreating content that closely, it‚Äôs not innovation‚Äîit‚Äôs imitation, and often based on data that may have been scraped or pirated without consent. Nothing new. The tech certainly gets better, but fake news has existed long, long before AI or computers... probably dating back to when humans first learned to speak & write - and definitely by the time that politics entered the picture. Fake news simply relies on the gullibility of people - on their willingness, and even obsession, to accept lies as truths, rumor & hearsay as fact - and not really so much on tech tricks. This has always been particularly effective when the false narrative plays into any already long held beliefs, or when the source of the narrative comes from a trusted source. Education plays a large part in establishing this behavior, since we are typically taught, esp. as children, to accept what we are told & shown, without question & without additional verification. WIll AI make this situation worse? Almost certainly, in the short-term. But, perhaps, over the long haul, it might actually force people to learn to question & verify more of what they see & hear, rather than accept it at face value. Disclaimer: Just my personal opinion, so feel free to disagree. :)

One way to tell something is AI generated is when lines are literally quite blurred to where surfaces are too smooth or detail is not quite there. Blemishes are also often removed with skin looking too smooth and especially water looking too glossy. Don't listen for vocal cues because human voice replication is getting more realistic by the month, but right now, you can still hear the AI voice slightly distorted as if the voice were recorded with a less-than-professional mic. Obvious AI content out there shows outlandish scenarios like a video that has "massive flood" in the title and shows a tsunami crashing through a fjord or valley with an impossible amount of water, or a YouTube short of a "giant sea monster" shows a massive octopus with 20 arms on a ship's deck. Nearly everybody understands physical body distortions like six or more fingers, growing extra limbs, and key details disappearing, so this is easy to spot. As mentioned in the video, words are still gibberish at this point with AI generations, but that may very well change before the year ends. Please be careful of what you watch and share, and if there is a video that doesn't post an AI disclaimer and very few people have mentioned it's AI, please do so yourself in the comments.
